Instructions_en:
I received 2 one-hour in-person lessons with a local high school age rider.  The lessons were very helpful even though some of the advice was bad (e.g., per what I had/have read online before and since and per my own personal experience since).  E.g., he advised me to look down just in front of the wheel while riding rather than to look up and much farther forward.

I learned to freemount and ride at the same time so my freemounts were getting pretty solid by the time I could ride 50 meters.  I think this is a great approach and would recommend it.  

I learned mostly on artificial turf (aka astroturf) soccer fields (and a little on grass fields) because they're softer to fall on compared to pavement.  On the one hand, this helped me to be more aggressive with my learning efforts, but on the other hand, the astroturf is soft and riding 50 meters on it turned out to be a lot more difficult than riding on pavement.  So I suspect I could have ridden 50 meters a little more quickly if I'd been riding on a hard surface (e.g., pavement or a gym floor would be ideal).  

I noticed several days where my learning advanced only after I'd already been practicing for 45 minutes, at a point where I was tired and would have expected my performance to be diminishing.  My instructor said he noticed the same when he was learning and advocated for minimum 1 hour practice sessions.  Most of my practice sessions were around 1 hour but some were as little as 30 minutes and a few as much as 1.5 hours.  

I found a few YouTube instructional videos very helpful.  In particular, the video â€œTips on how to free mount a 24" and a 36" unicycleâ€ (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yqWtEBgG300) really helped me understand that static free-mounting works best when you apply quite a lot of weight down through the saddle and handle.  That was extremely helpful for me.

These two Uniquest videos were also helpful for learning basic riding and freemounting:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rWUoIv1ftXc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ss8iPrDfTs0

I also read the book "How to Ride Your Unicycle" by Charlie Dancey.  I think this book was helpful and had a nice humorous tone.  Iâ€™d like to get his book on teaching unicycling, but I have not found it in stock on Unicycle.com so far.  

I kept careful track of my practice time and progress learning to unicycle (out of both idle curiosity and a habit of logging my fitness activities).
At 18 hours I static free-mounted and rode 50 meters for the first time. 
It wasnâ€™t until 22 hours that I managed to do that again and was subsequently able to ride farther than 50 meters regularly.

Feel free to contact me if you'd like comments on anything I didn't cover.  mike.roze@gmail.com

Remarks_en:
If I had known then:
For unicycle beginners, I recommend that the cranks are positioned horizontally after 'contacting' both pedals! NEVER try to drive off with one pedal down and one up - first load both pedals equally and stand upright, with only ONE hand on the wall / railing and sit down - while doing this, guide the saddle with your thighs so that it does not fall out, free arm as a balance bar. When pressure is applied to both pedals, you can alternate between releasing and increasing the pressure in your legs to move the bike while maintaining tension in your hips, back and stomach.
During the first 100 attempts, get used to letting the bike and saddle slam down so that you always land on your feet ðŸ˜‰

If at some point two free arms are no longer necessary for balance, one hand on the saddle handle can help with free ascents and jumps.

Requirements for the terrain:
Free ascent,
Commuting / driving backwards for overall control,
Jumping while standing AND while driving (long jump),
Driving over e.g. curbs without falling,
And the most important:
ACTIVE POSITION (saddle with buttocks in the back, sternum in front, cornering riding technique from the hips without arm rowing, balance by shifting the spine to the side instead of arm rowing),
After a while, a brake to be able to drive short cranks under 127mm downhill for a smoother step ...

Interesting thing for sure. As a trainer, I have learned that the length of time it takes to learn to ride a unicycle varies greatly. And I think the motivation is the most important thing ... Do I want to ride a unicycle myself or do I have to learn to ride a unicycle because someone else wants to? Do I have like-minded people who want to train with me and have the same goal? Family friends ... can i copy it from someone? does someone teach me? Do I have the right unicycle for me? And of course: What kind of movement experience do I have? All of these circumstances have an enormous influence on the duration of learning. Nice study;).
